content.title: Consumer Surplus
content.definition: Consumer surplus is the difference between the maximum amount consumers are willing to pay for a good or service and the actual amount they pay (market price). It represents the net benefit or gain that consumers receive from market participation.

definitions_glossary.willingness_to_pay: Maximum amount a consumer is willing to pay for a good - reflects their valuation or utility from consuming it
definitions_glossary.reservation_price: Highest price at which a consumer would still purchase the good - synonymous with willingness to pay
definitions_glossary.market_price: Actual price paid in the market - determined by supply and demand equilibrium
definitions_glossary.consumer_benefit: Total utility or satisfaction consumers gain from consumption
definitions_glossary.net_benefit: Consumer surplus = willingness to pay minus actual payment
definitions_glossary.demand_curve: Shows consumers' willingness to pay at different quantity levels - marginal benefit curve
definitions_glossary.marginal_consumer: Consumer whose willingness to pay equals market price - indifferent between buying and not buying

key_points: Consumer surplus = Total willingness to pay - Total expenditure (market price × quantity)
Graphically: Area between demand curve and market price, bounded by quantity purchased
Measures consumer welfare from market participation - 'good deal' consumers get
First introduced by Jules Dupuit (1844), formalized by Alfred Marshall (1890)
Higher prices reduce consumer surplus (consumers worse off), lower prices increase it (better off)
Perfect competition maximizes total surplus (consumer + producer) - allocative efficiency
Market interventions (taxes, price controls) typically reduce consumer surplus and create deadweight loss
Individual consumer surplus aggregates to market consumer surplus (sum across all consumers)
Assumes consumers are rational, have complete information, and face no transaction costs

examples.title: Concert Ticket Purchase
examples.description: You would pay up to $150 for a Taylor Swift concert ticket (your willingness to pay). You manage to buy it for $90 (market price). Your consumer surplus = $150 - $90 = $60. This represents your net gain from the transaction.
examples.context: Individual consumer surplus calculation - shows personal benefit from paying less than maximum willingness

examples.title: Gasoline Market with Price Increase
examples.description: Gasoline price rises from $3.00 to $4.50 per gallon due to supply disruption. Consumer at $3.00: willing to pay $5/gallon, actual $3, surplus = $2/gallon. At $4.50: willing to pay $5, actual $4.50, surplus = $0.50/gallon. Consumer surplus loss = $2 - $0.50 = $1.50 per gallon. For 1000 gallons/year = $1,500 annual welfare loss.
examples.context: Demonstrates how price increases reduce consumer surplus - welfare impact of supply shocks

examples.title: Sales Tax Impact
examples.description: Market equilibrium: P* = $50, Q* = 1000 units. Government imposes $10 sales tax. New price to consumers: Pb = $57. Quantity falls to Qt = 800. Consumer surplus: Before = 0.5 × (100 - 50) × 1000 = $25,000. After = 0.5 × (100 - 57) × 800 = $17,200. Consumer surplus loss = $7,800. Part becomes tax revenue, part is deadweight loss.
examples.context: Tax reduces both consumer surplus and market efficiency - welfare cost of taxation

examples.title: Price Ceiling in Rental Housing
examples.description: Free market rent: $2,000/month, equilibrium quantity: 10,000 apartments. Government sets rent ceiling: $1,500/month. Quantity supplied falls to 8,000 (shortage of 2,000 given demand would be 12,000). Winners: 8,000 renters get $500/month surplus ($6,000/year each). Losers: 2,000 potential renters shut out of market (loss = their willingness to pay - $1,500). Net effect: May increase or decrease total consumer surplus depending on distribution.
examples.context: Price ceilings redistribute consumer surplus but create deadweight loss from reduced quantity

content.statement: Consumer surplus measures the welfare gain that consumers receive from participating in markets, calculated as the difference between their total willingness to pay and their actual expenditure. It is a fundamental concept in welfare economics for evaluating market efficiency and the impact of economic policies.

explanation.intuition: Think of consumer surplus as getting a good deal. If you'd pay up to $100 for something but only pay $60, you've gained $40 in value - that's your consumer surplus. When you buy multiple units, each unit at or below your willingness to pay adds to your surplus. The demand curve shows how much people value each additional unit. The area between the demand curve and the price line represents all the 'good deals' consumers get - their total surplus.
explanation.key_insight: Consumer surplus reveals that markets create value beyond just transferring goods and money. It measures the difference between subjective value (what consumers would pay) and objective cost (what they actually pay). This gap is pure welfare gain - economic value created by trade. Competitive markets tend to maximize total surplus (consumer + producer), making them efficient. When policies disrupt markets (taxes, price controls), consumer surplus usually falls, indicating welfare loss. This makes consumer surplus crucial for cost-benefit analysis of policies.
explanation.technical_details: Mathematically: CS = ∫[0,Q*] P(Q) dQ - P* × Q*, where P(Q) is inverse demand function, P* is market price, Q* is quantity purchased. For linear demand P = a - bQ: CS = 0.5 × (a - P*) × Q* = 0.5 × (Pmax - P*) × Q*, where Pmax = a is choke price (price where demand = 0). Individual consumer surplus: CSi = ∫[0,qi] Pi(q) dq - P* × qi. Market consumer surplus: CS = Σi CSi = horizontal sum. Changes in CS: ΔCS = [0.5 × (Pmax - P1) × Q1] - [0.5 × (Pmax - P0) × Q0]. For small price changes: ΔCS ≈ -Q × ΔP (first-order approximation). Compensating variation: income needed to restore utility after price change. Equivalent variation: willingness to pay to avoid price change. Under constant marginal utility of income, CS ≈ CV ≈ EV.

mathematical_formulation.linear_demand: CS = 0.5 × (Pmax - P*) × Q*, where Pmax = a (choke price)
mathematical_formulation.discrete_units: CS = Σ[i=1,Q*] (WTPi - P*) for each unit i
mathematical_formulation.elasticity_relation: ΔCS/CS ≈ -Ed × (ΔP/P), where Ed = price elasticity of demand
mathematical_formulation.exact_change_formula: ΔCS = ∫[P0,P1] Q(P) dP (area to left of demand curve between prices)
mathematical_formulation.verification: Formulas verified: For linear demand Q = a - bP, CS = 0.5 × b × (Pmax - P*)² = 0.5 × (a/b - P*) × (a - bP*) = 0.5 × (a - bP*)²/b ✓

welfare_economics_role.efficiency_criterion: Competitive equilibrium maximizes total surplus (CS + PS) - Pareto efficient
welfare_economics_role.policy_evaluation: Compare CS before and after policy intervention - measure welfare impact
welfare_economics_role.deadweight_loss: Reduction in total surplus (CS + PS) from market distortions - inefficiency measure
welfare_economics_role.kaldor_hicks_criterion: Policy is efficient if winners' gains (ΔCS > 0) exceed losers' losses (ΔCS < 0)
welfare_economics_role.cost_benefit_analysis: Net social benefit = ΔCS + ΔPS + external effects
welfare_economics_role.distributional_concerns: CS measures aggregate welfare but not equity - $1 surplus has same weight regardless of who receives it

factors_affecting_consumer_surplus.price_level: Lower prices → higher CS. Each $1 price decrease increases CS by approximately current quantity sold
factors_affecting_consumer_surplus.demand_elasticity: More elastic demand → larger CS changes from price changes. Inelastic demand → smaller CS changes
factors_affecting_consumer_surplus.income_levels: Higher income typically increases willingness to pay → larger potential CS
factors_affecting_consumer_surplus.substitutes_availability: More substitutes → more elastic demand → smaller CS loss from price increases
factors_affecting_consumer_surplus.consumer_heterogeneity: Diverse willingness to pay → larger aggregate CS. Homogeneous consumers → smaller CS
factors_affecting_consumer_surplus.market_structure: Perfect competition maximizes CS. Monopoly reduces CS as price rises above marginal cost

measurement_challenges.willingness_to_pay_unobservable: Cannot directly observe individual WTP - must infer from behavior or surveys
measurement_challenges.demand_curve_estimation: Need econometric techniques to estimate demand - measurement error affects CS calculations
measurement_challenges.income_effects: CS assumes constant marginal utility of income - violated for large price changes or normal/inferior goods
measurement_challenges.consumer_rationality: Assumes rational consumers with stable preferences - behavioral economics shows violations
measurement_challenges.market_vs_survey_data: Revealed preference (market) vs. stated preference (survey) - may differ
measurement_challenges.aggregation_issues: Summing individual CS requires strong assumptions about utility comparability across people

concepts: Calculus: integration to find area under demand curve
Optimization: maximizing consumer utility subject to budget constraint
Behavioral economics: anchoring effects on willingness to pay
Loss aversion: consumers value losses more than equivalent gains
Tax incidence: distribution of tax burden and welfare effects

verified_claims.claim: Consumer surplus = ∫[0,Q*] P(Q) dQ - P* × Q*
verified_claims.derivation: CS = Total willingness to pay - Total expenditure. WTP = ∫[0,Q*] P(Q) dQ (area under demand). Expenditure = P* × Q*. Therefore CS = ∫[0,Q*] P(Q) dQ - P* × Q* ✓

verified_claims.claim: For linear demand, CS = 0.5 × (Pmax - P*) × Q*
verified_claims.derivation: Demand: P = a - bQ. Pmax = a (Q=0). CS = ∫[0,Q*] (a - bQ) dQ - P* × Q* = [aQ - 0.5bQ²]₀^Q* - P*Q* = aQ* - 0.5bQ*² - P*Q* = Q*(a - P*) - 0.5bQ*². Since P* = a - bQ*, we have a - P* = bQ*, so CS = Q*×bQ* - 0.5bQ*² = 0.5bQ*² = 0.5×(a-P*)×Q* ✓
